Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Pursuant to Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186, § 14, a landlord is liable for any restriction of a tenant’s quiet enjoyment caused by an act or omission, whether intentional or negligent.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 185C, \u00a7 20.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 185C, § 20, which vests the Housing Court with jurisdiction over disputes relating to rental housing conditions.

Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 41.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 417 Mass. 273, 276 (1994).
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 41.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every tenant is entitled to the covenant of quiet enjoyment, which guarantees freedom from serious interference with the use and enjoyment of their rental property.
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 41.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 41.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly discusses the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 and describes it as protecting a tenant’s right to be free from serious interference with the tenancy that impairs the character and value of the leasehold. It then applies that standard to conclude that inability to use common areas due to criminal activity would constitute a serious interference with tenants’ use and enjoyment of their homes. This aligns closely with the proposition that every tenant is entitled to a covenant of quiet enjoyment guaranteeing freedom from serious interference with use and enjoyment of rental property.
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 41.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 186, § 14, provides, in relevant part, that ‘any lessor or landlord who directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant’ shall be punished… The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. … In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development… then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment…”
